Authors: Maloney J., Resnick M., Rusk N., Silverman B., Eastmond E.
Title: The scratch programming language and environment
Source title: ACM Transactions on Computing Education
Affiliations: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, United States; MIT Media Laboratory, E14-464B, 75 Amherst St., Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Authors with affiliations: Maloney, J., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, United States, MIT Media Laboratory, E14-464B, 75 Amherst St., Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Resnick, M., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, United States; Rusk, N., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, United States; Silverman, B., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, United States; Eastmond, E., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, United States
Abstract: Scratch is a visual programming environment that allows users (primarily ages 8 to 16) to learn computer programming while working on personally meaningful projects such as animated stories and games. A key design goal of Scratch is to support self-directed learning through tinkering and collaboration with peers. This article explores how the Scratch programming language and environment support this goal. © 2010 ACM.
Author Keywords: Programming environment; Programming language; Scratch; Visual programming language
Index Keywords: Design goal; Programming environment; Programming language; Scratch; Self-directed learning; Visual programming environments; Visual programming languages; Ada (programming language); C (programming language); Computer programming

Authors: Lee M.J., Ko A.J., Kwan I.
Title: In-game assessments increase novice programmers' engagement and level completion speed
Source title: ICER 2013 - Proceedings of the 2013 ACM Conference on International Computing Education Research
Affiliations: University of Washington, Information School, United States; Oregon State University, School of EECS, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lee, M.J., University of Washington, Information School, United States, Oregon State University, School of EECS, United States; Ko, A.J., University of Washington, Information School, United States, Oregon State University, School of EECS, United States; Kwan, I., University of Washington, Information School, United States, Oregon State University, School of EECS, United States
Abstract: Assessments have been shown to have positive effects on learning in compulsory educational settings. However, much less is known about their effects in discretionary learning settings, especially in computing education and educational games. We hypothesized that adding assessments to an educational computing game would provide extra opportunities for players to practice and correct misconceptions, thereby affecting their performance on subsequent levels and their motivation to continue playing. To test this, we designed a game called Gidget, in which players help a robot find and fix defects in programs that follow a mastery learning paradigm. Across two studies, we manipulated the inclusion of multiple choice and self-explanation assessment levels in the game, measuring their impact on engagement and level completion speed. In our first study, we found that including assessments caused learners to voluntarily play longer and complete more levels, suggesting increased engagement; in our second study, we found that including assessments caused learners to complete levels faster, suggesting increased understanding. These findings suggest that including assessments in a discretionary computing education game may be a key design strategy for improving informal learning of computing concepts. Copyright © 2013 ACM.
Author Keywords: Assessment; Engagement, speed, debugging, serious game, educational game; Programming
Index Keywords: Assessment; Computing education; Design strategies; Educational settings; Informal learning; Learning settings; Self explanations; Serious games; Education; Learning systems; Mathematical programming; Computer games

Authors: Tsovaltzi D., Puhl T., Judele R., Weinberger A.
Title: Group awareness support and argumentation scripts for individual preparation of arguments in Facebook
Source title: Computers and Education
Affiliations: Educational Technology and Knowledge Management, Saarland University, 66123 Saarbrücken, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Tsovaltzi, D., Educational Technology and Knowledge Management, Saarland University, 66123 Saarbrücken, Germany; Puhl, T., Educational Technology and Knowledge Management, Saarland University, 66123 Saarbrücken, Germany; Judele, R., Educational Technology and Knowledge Management, Saarland University, 66123 Saarbrücken, Germany; Weinberger, A., Educational Technology and Knowledge Management, Saarland University, 66123 Saarbrücken, Germany
Abstract: This study investigates how group awareness support and argumentation scripts influence learning in social networking sites like Facebook, which may be conducive to informal learning, but often lacks argumentative quality. Supporting participants' group awareness about the visibility of the arguments they construct and about prospective future debate with peers in order to promote argument quality may be particularly suited for learning in Social Networking Sites. Additional argumentation scripts may directly foster argumentative knowledge construction. In a 2 × 2 study (N = 81), we isolated and investigated the effects of group awareness support and argumentation scripts during individual preparation in a Facebook app on domain and argumentative knowledge. Our results reveal that group awareness support of upcoming argumentative processes can be counterproductive for learning in Social Networking Sites. Argumentation scripts in Facebook may remedy possible negative effects of such awareness. Process analysis showed that group awareness support promotes individual argument elaboration but reduces broad analysis of the domain. © 2014 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Argumentation scripts; Argumentative knowledge construction; Facebook; Group awareness support
Index Keywords: Computer science; Education; Argument qualities; Argumentation scripts; Argumentative knowledge construction; Facebook; Group awareness; Informal learning; Process analysis; Social networking sites; Social networking (online)

Authors: Yang S., Domeniconi C., Revelle M., Sweeney M., Gelman B.U., Beckley C., Johri A.
Title: Uncovering trajectories of informal learning in large online communities of creators
Source title: L@S 2015 - 2nd ACM Conference on Learning at Scale
Affiliations: George Mason University, 4400 University Drive, Fairfax, VA  22030, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yang, S., George Mason University, 4400 University Drive, Fairfax, VA  22030, United States; Domeniconi, C., George Mason University, 4400 University Drive, Fairfax, VA  22030, United States; Revelle, M., George Mason University, 4400 University Drive, Fairfax, VA  22030, United States; Sweeney, M., George Mason University, 4400 University Drive, Fairfax, VA  22030, United States; Gelman, B.U., George Mason University, 4400 University Drive, Fairfax, VA  22030, United States; Beckley, C., George Mason University, 4400 University Drive, Fairfax, VA  22030, United States; Johri, A., George Mason University, 4400 University Drive, Fairfax, VA  22030, United States
Abstract: We analyzed informal learning in Scratch Online - an online community with over 4.3 million users and 6.7 million instances of user-generated content. Users develop projects, which are graphical interfaces consisting of interacting programming blocks. We investigated two fundamental questions of how we can model informal learning, and which patterns of informal learning emerge. We proceeded in two phases. First, we modeled learning as a trajectory of cumulative programming block usage by long-term users who created at least 50 projects. Second, we applied K-means++ clustering to uncover patterns of learning and corresponding subpopulations. We found four groups of users manifesting four different patterns of learning, ranging from the smallest to the largest improvement. At one end of the spectrum, users learned more and in a faster manner. At the opposite end, users did not show much learning progress, even after creating dozens of projects. The modeling and clustering of trajectory patterns that enabled us to quantitatively analyze informal learning may be applicable to other similar communities. The results can also support administrators of online communities in implementing customized interventions for specific subpopulations. Copyright © 2015 ACM.
Author Keywords: Clustering; Informal learning; Learning analytics; Modeling; Online community; Programming; Scratch
Index Keywords: Mathematical programming; Models; Online systems; Social networking (online); Trajectories; Websites; Clustering; Informal learning; Learning analytics; On-line communities; Scratch; E-learning

Authors: El-Bishouty M.M., Ogata H., Ayala G., Yano Y.
Title: Context-aware support for self-directed ubiquitous-learning
Source title: International Journal of Mobile Learning and Organisation
Affiliations: Department of Information Science and Intelligent Systems, The University of Tokushima, 2-1 Minami-Josanjima, 770-8506 Tokushima, Japan; Escuela de Ingeniería/School of Engineering, Universidad de las Américas, Sta. Catarina Mártir, Cholula, Puebla 72820, Mexico; Department of Information Science and Intelligent Systems, The University of Tokushima, 2-1 Minami-Josanjima, 770-8506 Tokushima, Japan
Authors with affiliations: El-Bishouty, M.M., Department of Information Science and Intelligent Systems, The University of Tokushima, 2-1 Minami-Josanjima, 770-8506 Tokushima, Japan; Ogata, H., Department of Information Science and Intelligent Systems, The University of Tokushima, 2-1 Minami-Josanjima, 770-8506 Tokushima, Japan; Ayala, G., Escuela de Ingeniería/School of Engineering, Universidad de las Américas, Sta. Catarina Mártir, Cholula, Puebla 72820, Mexico; Yano, Y., Department of Information Science and Intelligent Systems, The University of Tokushima, 2-1 Minami-Josanjima, 770-8506 Tokushima, Japan
Abstract: This research illustrates how ubiquitous technologies can be used to support self-directed learning. It presents the characteristics of the technology-supported self-directed ubiquitous-learning (TSUL) environments. Consequently, we present a model of an environment for supporting self- directed learners doing learning tasks or activities by utilising ubiquitous technologies. This environment allows the learners to interact with the physical world in order to develop their learning experiences in using the real objects. It provides personalised recommendations based on the detected context. It is observed that the environment stimulates self-directed learning and it received positive responses from the learners. © 2010 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.
Author Keywords: answer sets programming; ASP; context-awareness; intelligent agent; learner model; object-oriented recommendation; OOR; radio frequency identification; RFID; self-directed learning; technology-supported self-directed ubiquitous-learning; TSUL; ubiquitous- learning

Authors: Clegg T., Yip J.C., Ahn J., Bonsignore E., Gubbels M., Lewittes B., Rhodes E.
Title: When face-to-face fails: Opportunities for social media to foster collaborative learning
Source title: Computer-Supported Collaborative Learning Conference, CSCL
Affiliations: University of Maryland, 2117 Hornbake South Wing, College Park, MD 20742, United States
Authors with affiliations: Clegg, T., University of Maryland, 2117 Hornbake South Wing, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Yip, J.C., University of Maryland, 2117 Hornbake South Wing, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Ahn, J., University of Maryland, 2117 Hornbake South Wing, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Bonsignore, E., University of Maryland, 2117 Hornbake South Wing, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Gubbels, M., University of Maryland, 2117 Hornbake South Wing, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Lewittes, B., University of Maryland, 2117 Hornbake South Wing, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Rhodes, E., University of Maryland, 2117 Hornbake South Wing, College Park, MD 20742, United States
Abstract: Productive collaboration is an integral component of socially constructed perspectives of learning. Yet effective collaboration is quite challenging and not without its own risks. Collaboration, both distributed and face-to-face, must be nurtured; technologies can support or undermine its positive growth in learning communities. We present an exploratory investigation of the types of social interactions that are both productive and non-productive in face-to-face informal science learning contexts. We include an analysis of the ways in which social media technologies can be designed to support more collaborative interactions. © ISLS.
Index Keywords: Collaborative interaction; Collaborative learning; Informal science; Integral components; Learning community; Social interactions; Social media; Computer science

Authors: Fields D.A., Kafai Y.B., Giang M.T.
Title: Youth computational participation in the wild: Understanding experience and equity in participating and programming in the online Scratch community
Source title: ACM Transactions on Computing Education
Affiliations: Utah State University, 2830 Old Main Hill, Logan, UT  84322, United States; University of Pennsylvania, 3700 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, PA  19104, United States; Mount Saint Mary's University, 12001 Chalon Rd., Los Angeles, CA  90049, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fields, D.A., Utah State University, 2830 Old Main Hill, Logan, UT  84322, United States; Kafai, Y.B., University of Pennsylvania, 3700 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, PA  19104, United States; Giang, M.T., Mount Saint Mary's University, 12001 Chalon Rd., Los Angeles, CA  90049, United States
Abstract: Most research in primary and secondary computing education has focused on understanding learners within formal classroom communities, leaving aside the growing number of promising informal online programming communities where young users contribute, comment, and collaborate on programs to facilitate learning. In this article, we examined trends in computational participation in Scratch, an online community with over 1 million registered youth designers. Drawing on a random sample of 5,004 youth programmers and their activities over 3 months in early 2012, we examined programming concepts used in projects in relation to level of participation, gender, and length of membership of Scratch programmers. Latent class analysis results identified the same four groups of programmers in each month based on the usage of different programming concepts and showed how membership in these groups shifted in different ways across time. Strikingly, the largest group of project creators (named Loops) used the simplest and fewest programming concepts. Further, this group was the most stable in membership and was disproportionately female. In contrast, the more complex programming groups (named Variables, Low Booleans, and High Booleans) showed much movement across time. Further, the Low Booleans and High Booleans groups, the only groups to use "and," "or," and "not" statements in their programs, were disproportionately male. In the discussion, we address the challenges of analyzing young learners' programming in informal online communities and opportunities for designing more equitable computational participation. © 2017 ACM.
Author Keywords: Collaborative learning; Computer science education; Computer supported collaborative learning; Educational data mining; Equity; Learning analytics; Social networking forums; Social networking sites
Index Keywords: Data mining; E-learning; Education computing; Online systems; Social networking (online); Websites; Collaborative learning; Computer Science Education; Computer Supported Collaborative Learning; Educational data mining; Equity; Learning analytics; Social networking sites; Education

Authors: Dasgupta S., Hill B.M.
Title: Learning to code in localized programming languages
Source title: L@S 2017 - Proceedings of the 4th (2017) ACM Conference on Learning at Scale
Affiliations: MIT Media Lab, Cambridge, MA  02142, United States; University of Washington, Seattle, WA  98195, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dasgupta, S., MIT Media Lab, Cambridge, MA  02142, United States; Hill, B.M., University of Washington, Seattle, WA  98195, United States
Abstract: Education research suggests that learning in one's local language can have a positive impact on learning outcomes. We offer a quantitative test of the association between local language use and the rate at which youth learn to program. Using longitudinal data drawn from five countries and over 15,000 users of Scratch, a large informal learning community, we find that novice users who code with their programming language keywords and environment localized into their home countries' primary language demonstrate new programming concepts at a faster rate than users from the same countries whose interface is in English. We conclude with a discussion of the implications of our findings for designers of online learning systems. © 2017 ACM.
Author Keywords: H.5.2 Information interfaces and presentation (e.g. HCI): User interfaces; K.3.2 Computer and information science education: Computer science education
Index Keywords: Online systems; Software testing; User interfaces; Computer Science Education; Education research; Informal learning; Information interfaces and presentations; Longitudinal data; On-line learning systems; Programming concepts; Quantitative tests; Education computing

Authors: Gelman B.U., Beckley C., Johri A., Domeniconi C., Yang S.
Title: Online urbanism: Interest-based subcultures as drivers of informal learning in an online community
Source title: L@S 2016 - Proceedings of the 3rd 2016 ACM Conference on Learning at Scale
Affiliations: George Mason University, 4400 University Drive, Fairfax, VA  22030, United States; Louisiana State University, 267 Coates Hall, Baton Rouge, LA  70803, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gelman, B.U., George Mason University, 4400 University Drive, Fairfax, VA  22030, United States; Beckley, C., George Mason University, 4400 University Drive, Fairfax, VA  22030, United States; Johri, A., George Mason University, 4400 University Drive, Fairfax, VA  22030, United States; Domeniconi, C., George Mason University, 4400 University Drive, Fairfax, VA  22030, United States; Yang, S., Louisiana State University, 267 Coates Hall, Baton Rouge, LA  70803, United States
Abstract: Online communities continue to be an important resource for informal learning. Although many facets of online learning communities have been studied, we have limited understanding of how such communities grow over time to productively engage a large number of learners. In this paper we present a study of a large online community called Scratch which was created to help users learn software programming. We analyzed 5 years of data consisting of 1 million users and their 1.9 million projects. Examination of interactional patterns among highly active members of the community uncovered a markedly temporal dimension to participation. As membership of the Scratch online community grew over time, interest-based subcultures started to emerge. This pattern was uncovered even when clustering was based solely on social network of members. This process, which closely resembles urbanism or the growth of physically populated areas, allowed new members to combine their interests with programming. © 2016 ACM.
Author Keywords: Informal learning; Interest-based subcultures; Online communities; Programming; Scratch
Index Keywords: Mathematical programming; Online systems; Regional planning; Social networking (online); Websites; Active member; Informal learning; Interest-based subcultures; On-line communities; Online learning community; Scratch; Software programming; Temporal dimensions; E-learning

Authors: García-Peñalvo F.J., Zangrando V., Holgado A.G., Conde González M.A., Seoane-Pardo A.-M., Alier M., Galanis N., López J., Janssen J., Brouns F., Finders A., Berlanga A., Sloep P., Griffiths D., Johnson M., Waszkiewicz E., Mykowska A., Minovic M., Milovanovic M., Marques M.A., Viegas M.C., Alves G.R.
Title: A tool to aid institutions recognize their employees competences acquired by informal learning
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: TRAILER Project, Spain
Authors with affiliations: García-Peñalvo, F.J., TRAILER Project, Spain; Zangrando, V., TRAILER Project, Spain; Holgado, A.G., TRAILER Project, Spain; Conde González, M.A., TRAILER Project, Spain; Seoane-Pardo, A.-M., TRAILER Project, Spain; Alier, M., TRAILER Project, Spain; Galanis, N., TRAILER Project, Spain; López, J., TRAILER Project, Spain; Janssen, J., TRAILER Project, Spain; Brouns, F., TRAILER Project, Spain; Finders, A., TRAILER Project, Spain; Berlanga, A., TRAILER Project, Spain; Sloep, P., TRAILER Project, Spain; Griffiths, D., TRAILER Project, Spain; Johnson, M., TRAILER Project, Spain; Waszkiewicz, E., TRAILER Project, Spain; Mykowska, A., TRAILER Project, Spain; Minovic, M., TRAILER Project, Spain; Milovanovic, M., TRAILER Project, Spain; Marques, M.A., TRAILER Project, Spain; Viegas, M.C., TRAILER Project, Spain; Alves, G.R., TRAILER Project, Spain
Abstract: People do not learn only in formal educational institutions, but also throughout their lives, from their experiences, conversations, observations of others, exploration of the Internet, meetings and conferences, and chance encounters etc. However this informal and non-formal learning can easily remain largely invisible, making it hard for peers and employers to recognize or act upon it. The TRAILER project aims to make this learning visible so that it can benefit both the individual and the organization. The proposed demonstration will show a software solution that (i) helps the learners to capture, organize and classify a wide range of 'informal' learning taking place in their lives, and (ii) assists the organization in recognizing this learning and use it to help managing human resources (benefiting both parts). This software tool has recently been used in two phases of pilot studies, which have run in four different European countries. © 2013 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: informal learning; non-formal learning; software tool; tagging competences
Index Keywords: Educational institutions; European Countries; Informal learning; Non-formal learning; Pilot studies; Software solution; tagging competences; Artificial intelligence; Computer aided software engineering; Computer science; Computer software

Authors: Holland A.A.
Title: Effective principles of informal online learning design: A theory-building metasynthesis of qualitative research
Source title: Computers and Education
Affiliations: Hamline University and University of Minnesota, United States
Authors with affiliations: Holland, A.A., Hamline University and University of Minnesota, United States
Abstract: Informal online learning is the unstructured learning that happens in daily life while people are accessing the internet. Research on the use and design of interactive Web 2.0 platforms for informal learning is minimal, and often platform-specific. This theory-building metasynthesis aims to identify what is known about how informal online learning can be effectively designed outside a formal online course structure. The study reviewed 22 articles that investigated learning that happened primarily online, was self-directed in nature, and had a primarily adult audience. The author brought together the findings of these individual studies to identified two effective principles of informal online learning design that research dissemination organizations can utilize when developing online outreach education programs for adult audiences: (a) interaction opportunities support knowledge construction and learner empowerment; and (b) segmented, titled, and tagged learning objects facilitate personalized learning. The principles identified in this study not only describe what is known about how adults learn informally online, but also provide the common language and goals to frame the interdisciplinary collaboration likely necessary to employ them. © 2018
Author Keywords: Adult learning; Computer-mediated communication; Distance education; Lifelong learning; Telelearning
Index Keywords: Computer science; Distance education; Education; Adult learning; Computer mediated communication; Informal online learning; Interdisciplinary collaborations; Life long learning; Personalized learning; Telelearning; Unstructured learning; E-learning

Authors: Tuomi P., Multisilta J., Saarikoski P., Suominen J.
Title: Coding skills as a success factor for a society
Source title: Education and Information Technologies
Affiliations: Department of Pori, Tampere University of Technology, Pohjoisranta 11A, Pori, 28101, Finland; University of Turku, Pori Unit, Pohjoisranta 11A, Pori, 28101, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Tuomi, P., Department of Pori, Tampere University of Technology, Pohjoisranta 11A, Pori, 28101, Finland; Multisilta, J., Department of Pori, Tampere University of Technology, Pohjoisranta 11A, Pori, 28101, Finland; Saarikoski, P., University of Turku, Pori Unit, Pohjoisranta 11A, Pori, 28101, Finland; Suominen, J., University of Turku, Pori Unit, Pohjoisranta 11A, Pori, 28101, Finland
Abstract: Digitalization is one of the most promising ways to increase productivity in the public sector and is needed to reform the economy by creating new innovation related jobs. The implementation of digital services requires problem solving, design skills, logical thinking, an understanding of how computers and networks operate, and programming competence. These abilities can be considered as coding skills. The aim of the study is to find and classify the different approaches and methods of promoting and learning coding skills. In addition, coding initiatives in Finland are analyzed both from both an historical and a present-day point of view. As a result, we identified three different approaches to learning coding skills: 1) in formal settings (schools within the curriculum); 2) in non-formal settings (online, after school clubs); 3) in informal events (hackathons, jams etc.). In many cases, schools are utilizing coding events and materials created by non-profit organizations, governments, or companies. Coding is also learned in after school clubs on robotics or by creating devices using cheap computing hardware such as the Raspberry Pi. © 2017, Springer Science+Business Media New York.
Author Keywords: Coding; Computational thinking; Computer programming; Education; Maker culture

Authors: Kafai Y., Roque R., Fields D., Monroy-Hernandez A.
Title: Collaboration by choice: Youth online creative collabs in Scratch
Source title: Proceedings of the 19th International Conference on Computers in Education, ICCE 2011
Affiliations: Graduate School of Education, University of Pennsylvania, United States; Media Lab., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kafai, Y., Graduate School of Education, University of Pennsylvania, United States; Roque, R., Media Lab., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, United States; Fields, D., Graduate School of Education, University of Pennsylvania, United States; Monroy-Hernandez, A., Media Lab., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, United States
Abstract: Online creative production has received considerable attention for its success in creating Wikipedia and Free and Open Source Software yet few youth participate in such voluntary online collaborations, in particular in programming contexts. In this paper, we describe how youth programmers organized collaborative groups or collabs in response to a design challenge in the Scratch Online Community. We report on participation in the "Collab Challenge" in the Scratch community at large and with particular groups, designers' efforts in recruiting and organizing collab groups, and the role of community feedback. In the discussion, we address what we learned about youth's informal collaborative skills, fostering community participation, and the design of online communities supportive of creative collaboration, and open issues for further research.
Author Keywords: Collaboration; Online community; Programming
Index Keywords: Collaboration; Collaborative groups; Community participation; Design challenges; Free and open source softwares; Online collaboration; Online communities; Wikipedia; Mathematical programming; Websites; Online systems

Authors: Kashihara A., Kamoshita Y.
Title: Reflection by knowledge publishing
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Dept. of Information and Communication Engineering, University of Electro-Communications, 1-5-1, Chofugaoka, Chofu, Tokyo, 182-8585, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kashihara, A., Dept. of Information and Communication Engineering, University of Electro-Communications, 1-5-1, Chofugaoka, Chofu, Tokyo, 182-8585, Japan; Kamoshita, Y., Dept. of Information and Communication Engineering, University of Electro-Communications, 1-5-1, Chofugaoka, Chofu, Tokyo, 182-8585, Japan
Abstract: Self-directed learning often finishes with incomplete knowledge. It is hard for learners to be aware of the knowledge incompleteness. The main issue addressed in this paper is how to enhance their awareness. Our approach to this issue is to enable learners to publish knowledge obtained from their learning process to review it. The most important point towards knowledge publishing is how to represent knowledge so that the learners can reflect on it from another perspective. However, such knowledge representation would be troublesome for the learners. This paper discusses how to promote learners' knowledge publishing by automatically generating a hypertext with TOC (Table Of Contents) as representation of knowledge they have learned in their learning process. Publishing the hypertext enables the learners to gain not only their own reviews but also the reviews from the peers. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2006.
Index Keywords: Computer science; HTML; Learning systems; Knowledge publishing; Self-directed learning; Table Of Contents; Knowledge representation

Authors: Haythornthwaite C., Kumar P., Gruzd A., Gilbert S., Esteve del Valle M., Paulin D.
Title: Learning in the wild: coding for learning and practice on Reddit
Source title: Learning, Media and Technology
Affiliations: School of Information Studies, Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY, United States; Social Media Lab, Ryerson University, Toronto, Canada; Ted Rogers School of Management, Ryerson University, Toronto, Canada; The iSchool, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada; Department of Media Studies and Journalism, University of Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands; School of Information, University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Haythornthwaite, C., School of Information Studies, Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY, United States; Kumar, P., Social Media Lab, Ryerson University, Toronto, Canada; Gruzd, A., Ted Rogers School of Management, Ryerson University, Toronto, Canada; Gilbert, S., The iSchool, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada; Esteve del Valle, M., Department of Media Studies and Journalism, University of Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands; Paulin, D., School of Information, University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States
Abstract: Learning on and through social media is becoming a cornerstone of lifelong learning, creating places not only for accessing information, but also for finding other self-motivated learners. Such is the case for Reddit, the online news sharing site that is also a forum for asking and answering questions. We studied learning practices found in ‘Ask’ subreddits AskScience, Ask_Politics, AskAcademia, and AskHistorians to develop a coding schema for informal learning. This paper describes the process of evaluating and defining a workable coding schema, one that started with attention to learning processes associated with discourse, exploratory talk, and conversational dialogue, and ended with including norms and practices on Reddit and the support of communities of inquiry. Our ‘learning in the wild’ coding schema contributes a content analysis schema for learning through social media, and an understanding of how knowledge, ideas, and resources are shared in open, online learning forums. © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
Author Keywords: coding; content analysis; Informal learning; Reddit; social media

Authors: Wang A.Y., Mitts R., Guo P.J., Chilana P.K.
Title: Mismatch of expectations: How modern learning resources fail conversational programmers
Source title: Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems - Proceedings
Affiliations: Computing Science, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC, Canada; Design Lab, UC San Diego, San Diego, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, A.Y., Computing Science, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC, Canada; Mitts, R., Computing Science, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC, Canada; Guo, P.J., Design Lab, UC San Diego, San Diego, CA, United States; Chilana, P.K., Computing Science, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC, Canada
Abstract: Conversational programmers represent a class of learners who are not required to write any code, yet try to learn pro-gramming to improve their participation in technical con-versations. We carried out interviews with 23 conversation-al programmers to better understand the challenges they face in technical conversations, what resources they choose to learn programming, how they perceive the learning pro-cess, and to what extent learning programming actually helps them. Among our key findings, we found that conver-sational programmers often did not know where to even begin the learning process and ended up using formal and informal learning resources that focus largely on program-ming syntax and logic. However, since the end goal of con-versational programmers was not to build artifacts, modern learning resources usually failed these learners in their pur-suits of improving their technical conversations. Our find-ings point to design opportunities in HCI to invent learner-centered approaches that address the needs of conversation-al programmers and help them establish common ground in technical conversations. © 2018 Association for Computing Machinery.
Author Keywords: Conversational programmers; Learner-centered design; Pro-gramming literacy; Technical conversations
Index Keywords: Computation theory; Human computer interaction; Human engineering; Conversational programmers; Informal learning; Learner centered design; Learner-centered approach; Learning programming; Learning resource; Pro-gramming literacy; Technical conversations; Learning systems

Authors: Galanis N., Mayol E., Alier M., Garcia-Peñalvo F.J.
Title: Designing an informal learning support framework
Source title: ACM International Conference Proceeding Series
Affiliations: Universidad Politécnica de Catalunya, BarcelonaTech, UPC Campus Nord, Omega S206 Girona 1-3, Barcelona, 08034, Spain; Universidad de Salamanca, Plaza de los Caídos s/n, Salamanca, 37008, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Galanis, N., Universidad Politécnica de Catalunya, BarcelonaTech, UPC Campus Nord, Omega S206 Girona 1-3, Barcelona, 08034, Spain; Mayol, E., Universidad Politécnica de Catalunya, BarcelonaTech, UPC Campus Nord, Omega S206 Girona 1-3, Barcelona, 08034, Spain; Alier, M., Universidad Politécnica de Catalunya, BarcelonaTech, UPC Campus Nord, Omega S206 Girona 1-3, Barcelona, 08034, Spain; Garcia-Peñalvo, F.J., Universidad de Salamanca, Plaza de los Caídos s/n, Salamanca, 37008, Spain
Abstract: Informal learning, alongside competence-based learning and learning outcomes is getting a lot of attention lately. A large number of countries and organizations are busy defining guidelines for validating and evaluating informal learning experiences and formalizing its outcomes. In a globalized society where technology has brought together different cultures and educational systems, managing to keep track of a learneŕs competences is a daunting task, and especially when trying to take into account the competences acquired through informal means. We are proposing a framework to gather, organize, evaluate and showcase a user's informal learning using a largely social approach. © 2015 ACM.
Author Keywords: E-learning; ELearning; Evaluation; Informal learning; Lifelong learning; Non-formal learning; Social learning; Validation
Index Keywords: E-learning; Ecology; Evaluation; Informal learning; Life long learning; Non-formal learning; Social learning; Validation; Ecosystems

Authors: Caruana S.
Title: An intelligent electronic assessment system
Source title: Proceedings of the IADIS International Conference e-Learning 2010, Part of the IADIS Multi Conference on Computer Science and Information Systems 2010, MCCSIS 2010
Affiliations: Computer Information Systems Department, Faculty of Information and Communication Technology, University of Malta, Malta
Authors with affiliations: Caruana, S., Computer Information Systems Department, Faculty of Information and Communication Technology, University of Malta, Malta
Abstract: The use of Information and Communication Technology (ICT) in order to enable learners to get accreditation and recognition for the different forms of informal learning that takes place is a challenging scenario. This paper proposes a setup whereby the learner not only is able to get a formal type of accreditation within a recognized institution but it is able to provide a series of connections whereby the learner can see where the knowledge that he/she has chosen would be leading to. Alternatively, the learner may depart from a series of skills/knowledge that he/she requires and the proposed system will provide leads to web-based knowledge repositories that may enable the learner to embark on a learning process. © 2010 IADIS.
Author Keywords: Connectivism; E-assessment; E-learning; E-portfolios; Intelligent assessment system (IAS)
Index Keywords: Assessment system; Connectivism; E-assessment; E-portfolios; Informal learning; Information and Communication Technologies; Intelligent assessment systems; Intelligent electronics; Knowledge repository; Learning process; Accreditation; Computer science; E-learning; Engineering education; Information systems; Rating; Learning systems

Authors: Doliiiska I.
Title: Simple blog searching framework based on social network analysis
Source title: Proceedings of the International Multiconference on Computer Science and Information Technology, IMCSIT 2010
Affiliations: University of Economics and Computer Science in Warsaw, StoklŁosy 3, 02-787 Warsaw, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Doliiiska, I., University of Economics and Computer Science in Warsaw, StoklŁosy 3, 02-787 Warsaw, Poland
Abstract: Blogs are very popular Internet communication tools. The process of knowledge sharing is a very important activity in the contemporary information era. Blogs are used for knowledge sharing on any subject all over the world. Knowledge gathered 011 blogs can be used in personal e-learning. which is a more informal and personal way of learning than the one offered by traditional e-learning courses. However, it is not easy to find valuable knowledge in the huge amount of invalid information. In this study the Simple Blog Searching framework is proposed to improve the blog searching process. The social network analysis methods of centrality measuring help to choose more easily the best results form the long list of hits, received from a blog search tool. To incorporate social network analysis methods, the blog searching have to be expanded with the blog links searching. © 2010 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Blog search; Internet communication; Knowledge-sharing; Social Network Analysis; Blogs; Computer science; E-learning; Electric network analysis; Information technology; Knowledge management; Internet

Authors: Haaranen L., Duran R.
Title: Link between gaming communities in YouTube & computer science
Source title: CSEDU 2017 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Computer Supported Education
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Aalto University, Helsinki, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Haaranen, L., Department of Computer Science, Aalto University, Helsinki, Finland; Duran, R., Department of Computer Science, Aalto University, Helsinki, Finland
Abstract: Playing games has become a permanent part of popular culture, and the number of players keeps increasing. Part of this phenomenon is the act of recording gameplay and sharing the videos creating online gaming communities. We describe different types of gaming videos that intersect with learning computer science (CS). In addition, we looked at the discussions those videos spurred and found a rich interaction with CS topics. Since games can act as an engaging environment for informal learning, we conclude that the gaming community has relevant connections to learning CS and we as the research community should pay more attention to this phenomenon. © 2017 by SCITEPRESS - Science and Technology Publications, Lda. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Computer science education; Game-based learning; Informal learning
Index Keywords: Education; Education computing; Electronic document exchange; Computer Science Education; Game-based Learning; Gameplay; Informal learning; On-line gaming; Popular cultures; Research communities; YouTube; Computer games

Authors: Dron J., Anderson T.
Title: Learning with strangers the value of sets in online learning
Source title: CSEDU 2014 - Proceedings of the 6th International Conference on Computer Supported Education
Affiliations: Technology-enhanced Knowledge Research Institute, Athabasca University, University Drive, Athabasca, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Dron, J., Technology-enhanced Knowledge Research Institute, Athabasca University, University Drive, Athabasca, Canada; Anderson, T., Technology-enhanced Knowledge Research Institute, Athabasca University, University Drive, Athabasca, Canada
Abstract: Most research and practice relating to online and distance learning to date has focused on the social form of the intentional group, a named collection of people, typically hierarchically organized, with norms and/or explicit rules of conduct as well as inclusion or exclusion, membership, pacing and shared goals. The group provides a backdrop and infrastructure support for formal or informal learning activities. Since the last decade of the 20th century a different social form, the network, has been the subject of much research in informal and non-formal learning. Increasingly, however, we teach and we learn with and from countless anonymous others that are not formed into either identifiable networks or groups. We describe a collection of people who share little apart from interests or attributes but that none-the-less affect one another's learning as the Set. Under the right conditions, collective intelligence (or collectives) can emerge from such sets that can actively guide learning. In this paper we explore the nature of set-based learning and the role that collectives can play in helping or hindering learning.
Author Keywords: Collective; E-learning; Education; Group; Learning technology; Lifelong learning; Network; Set; Social media
Index Keywords: Computer science; Computers; Education; Networks (circuits); Collective; Group; Learning technology; Life long learning; Set; Social media; E-learning

Authors: Jiugen Y., Ruonan X., Xiaoqiang H.
Title: Constructing informal learning mode based on social software
Source title: ICCSE 2011 - 6th International Conference on Computer Science and Education, Final Program and Proceedings
Affiliations: Education School, Vocational Education Institute, Jiangxi Science and Technology Normal University, Nanchang, China; Communication School, Jiangxi Normal University, Nanchang, China
Authors with affiliations: Jiugen, Y., Education School, Vocational Education Institute, Jiangxi Science and Technology Normal University, Nanchang, China; Ruonan, X., Communication School, Jiangxi Normal University, Nanchang, China; Xiaoqiang, H., Education School, Vocational Education Institute, Jiangxi Science and Technology Normal University, Nanchang, China
Abstract: In order to meet learner changes of learning state diversity, informal learning has been gradually entering our field of vision, it becomes a important form of learner's learning. And social network is a coming Internet revolution, It is particularly important to carry out informal learning with the help of social software. The thesis introduces two basic concept, Social software and informal learning and analyzes the feasibility of informal learning with social software. Finally it concludes four usual informal learning modes: acceptance informal learning, self-directed informal learning, collaborative informal learning and Inquiry informal learning. © 2011 IEEE.
Author Keywords: construction; informal learning; learning mode; social software
Index Keywords: Basic concepts; Informal learning; Internet revolution; Learning mode; Social Networks; Social software; Computer science; Education computing; Social sciences computing; Computer software

Authors: Peña J.
Title: Seeding the Computational Skills of Diverse Non-programmers through Non-formal Workshops
Source title: ICER 2019 - Proceedings of the 2019 ACM Conference on International Computing Education Research
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State University University, Park, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Peña, J., Pennsylvania State University University, Park, PA, United States
Abstract: Non-programmers, in particular, those who identify as female or gender-diverse, experience many factors that hinder their ultimate interest, participation, and success in programming. Prior work has delved into the problem of underrepresentation in STEM and specifically in Computing Education to uncover the barriers impacting these groups. Yet, attraction and retention remains a challenge. I argue that while formal learning pathways are critical to increasing participation of diverse learners, it is also integral to provide informal and non-formal learning opportunities as well. My research uses mixed-methods within a design-based research approach to offer and evaluate an active learning beginners’ programming workshop called Code For Her. The workshop is designed to introduce females and gender-diverse individuals to web development. My goal is to analyze participants’ experiences and progress within a trajectory framework, producing a narrative of their behaviors and attitudes over both short-term and longer-term intervals. In a pilot study of the workshop design, I observed increases in self-efficacy and positive attitudes, as well as changes in ways of thinking about computing. I note that the brief exposure of a workshop may seed understanding and skills in computation, but is not likely to convert non-programmers into programmers. Instead, I am exploring a new construct - computational grounding - that refers to participants’ enhanced orientation toward computing-related behaviors. I will operationalize and study this construct using the workshop activities, thereby enhancing discussions of computational thinking. © 2019 Copyright held by the owner/author(s).
Author Keywords: Coding workshop; Gender; Informal learning; Non-programmers
Index Keywords: Computer programming; Coding workshop; Computational skills; Computational thinkings; Design-based research; Gender; Informal learning; Non-formal learning; Non-programmers; Computer science

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Retraction: Gender Reputation Differences on Online Programming Q&A Communities (Journal of Computer Information Systems, (2019), (1-10), 10.1080/08874417.2018.1563007)
Source title: Journal of Computer Information Systems
Abstract: The following article has been retracted from publication: Article title: Gender Reputation Differences on Online Programming Q&A Communities Authors: Yi Wang Journal: Journal of Computer Information SystemsVersion of Record Published Online: 01 February 2019 DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/08874417.2018.1563007 Statement of Retraction: We, the Editor and Publisher of Journal of Computer Information Systems, have retracted the above mentioned article. We are retracting this article because of significant overlap in structure, research questions, methods, findings, figures, and tables with the article entitled Gender Differences in Participation and Reward on Stack Overflow: May, A., Wachs, J. & Hannák, A. Empir Software Eng (2019). https://doi.org/10.1007/s10664-019-09685-x. The author has admitted to this misconduct and apologizes for it. We have been informed in our decision-making by our policy on publishing ethics and integrity and the COPE guidelines on retractions. The retracted article will remain online to maintain the scholarly record, but it will be digitally watermarked on each page as “Retracted.”. © 2019, © 2019 International Association for Computer Information Systems.

Authors: Wang Y.
Title: Gender Reputation Differences on Online Programming Q&A Communities
Source title: Journal of Computer Information Systems
Affiliations: Rochester Institute of Technology, Rochester, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Y., Rochester Institute of Technology, Rochester, NY, United States
Abstract: Women are underrepresented in the software development labor market. Many women utilize online programming Q&A communities to gain access to technical fields. They serve as a knowledge base for informal learning and provide opportunities for individuals to exhibit credible, verifiable expertise for career advancement. However, they are often male-oriented and create barriers for women to participate and earn reputations. We develop an understanding of how male and female developers participate in the online Q&A communities and how their participation impacts their successfulness regarding reputations. Using the data from the Stack Overflow, we quantitatively examine the differences in behavior and outcomes between men and women. The results reveal significant differences in how men and women participate and how successful they are, for example, women have lower reputations on average which are mostly resulting from women and men’s differences in their activities. We further discuss designing an alternative gender-neutral reputation mechanism. © 2018, © 2018 International Association for Computer Information Systems.
Author Keywords: Gender; online Q&A community; reputation; Stack Overflow
Index Keywords: Knowledge based systems; Career advancement; Gender; Informal learning; On-line programming; reputation; Reputation mechanism; Stack overflow; Technical fields; Software design

Authors: Thayer K., Guo P.J., Reinecke K.
Title: The impact of culture on learner behavior in visual debuggers
Source title: Proceedings of IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centric Computing, VL/HCC
Affiliations: Paul G. Allen School of Computer Science Engineering, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States; Dept. of Cognitive Science, UC San Diego, San Diego, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thayer, K., Paul G. Allen School of Computer Science Engineering, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States; Guo, P.J., Dept. of Cognitive Science, UC San Diego, San Diego, CA, United States; Reinecke, K., Paul G. Allen School of Computer Science Engineering, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, United States
Abstract: People around the world are learning to code using online resources. However, research has found that these learners might not gain equal benefit from such resources, in particular because culture may affect how people learn from and use online resources. We therefore expect to see cultural differences in how people use and benefit from visual debuggers. We investigated the use of one popular online debugger which allows users to execute Python code and navigate bidirectionally through the execution using forward-steps and back-steps. We examined behavioral logs of 78,369 users from 69 countries and conducted an experiment with 522 participants from 82 countries. We found that people from countries that tend to prefer self-directed learning (such as those from countries with a low Power Distance, which tend to be less hierarchical than others) used about twice as many back-steps. We also found that for individuals whose values aligned with instructor-directed learning (those who scored high on a 'Conservation' scale), back-steps were associated with less debugging success. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Non-linear learning; Program visualization. cross-cultural studies
Index Keywords: Computer programming; Computer science; Cross-cultural study; Cultural difference; How people learn; Low Power; Nonlinear learning; Online resources; Python code; Self-directed learning; Visual languages

Authors: Wang Y.
Title: Understanding the Reputation Differences between Women and Men on Stack Overflow
Source title: Proceedings - Asia-Pacific Software Engineering Conference, APSEC
Affiliations: Department of Software Engineering Rochester, Institute of Technology RochesterNY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Y., Department of Software Engineering Rochester, Institute of Technology RochesterNY, United States
Abstract: Women are underrepresented in the software development workforce which provides many well-paying jobs and career advancements. Many women utilize various online communities to gain access to technical fields. Among many such online communities, online programming Q&A communities are particularly important by serving as knowledge bases for self-directed informal learning and providing opportunities for individuals to exhibit their credible, verifiable expertise for career opportunities and advancements. However, these Q&A communities are often male-oriented, hence may create barriers for women to participate and earn reputations. In this paper, we aim to develop an understanding towards how male and female developers participate in the online Q&A communities and how their participation impacts their successfulness in terms of reputations. Using the data from the Stack Overflow, we quantitative examine the differences in behavior and outcomes between men and women. Our analyses reveal significant differences in how men and women participate in the online Q&A community and how successful they are. For example, women have much lower reputations on average which are mostly resulting from women and men's differences in their activities. We further discuss the potential design implications. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: female developer; gender; online Q&A community; reputation
Index Keywords: Online systems; Social networking (online); Career advancement; Career opportunities; Design implications; female developer; gender; On-line communities; On-line programming; reputation; Software design

Authors: De Backer L., Kollar I., Williams C., Seufert T., Weinberger A., Melzner N., Greisel M., Dresel M., Kielstra J., Molenaar I., Van Keer H., Valcke M., Hämäläinen R.
Title: Assessing prerequisites and processes of self-, co-and shared regulation during collaborative learning
Source title: Proceedings of International Conference of the Learning Sciences, ICLS
Affiliations: Ghent University, Belgium; Augsburg University, Belgium; University of Ulm, Germany; Saarland University, Germany; University of Augsburg, Belgium; Radboud University, Nijmegen, Netherlands; University of Jyväskylä, Finland
Authors with affiliations: De Backer, L., Ghent University, Belgium; Kollar, I., Augsburg University, Belgium; Williams, C., University of Ulm, Germany; Seufert, T., University of Ulm, Germany; Weinberger, A., Saarland University, Germany; Melzner, N., University of Augsburg, Belgium; Greisel, M., University of Augsburg, Belgium; Dresel, M., University of Augsburg, Belgium; Kielstra, J., Radboud University, Nijmegen, Netherlands; Molenaar, I., Radboud University, Nijmegen, Netherlands; Van Keer, H., Ghent University, Belgium; Valcke, M., Ghent University, Belgium; Hämäläinen, R., University of Jyväskylä, Finland
Abstract: To conceptualize regulation processes that may occur within groups, a differentiation between self-regulation (i.e., individual members regulate their own learning during collaboration), co-regulation (i.e., single learners regulate the learning of one or more of their learning partners), and shared regulation (i.e., the whole group regulates its learning) has been proposed. This symposium assembles four papers that offer various ways regarding the measurement of prerequisites and processes of such regulatory efforts during group learning. The presented methods range from Likert-scale self-report questionnaires over video case vignettes towards an analysis of real group processes by aid of logfiles and discourse coding schemes. These methods will be critically discussed, especially in terms of their transferability to studying collaborative learning in diverse educational contexts, both formal and informal. That way, the symposium will significantly expand previous methods for the assessment of self-, co-and shared regulation during collaborative learning. © ISLS.
Index Keywords: Surveys; Co-regulation; Coding scheme; Collaborative learning; Educational context; Group learning; Group process; Regulation process; Self regulation; E-learning

Authors: Bencivenga R.
Title: Adults’ perception of MOOC as part of a constellation of cultural experiences
Source title: Communications in Computer and Information Science
Affiliations: LEGS - Laboratoire d’études de genre et de sexualité UMR 8238, CNRS – Paris 8 - Paris OUEST, 27, rue Paul Bert, Ivry-sur-Seine Cedex, 94204, France
Authors with affiliations: Bencivenga, R., LEGS - Laboratoire d’études de genre et de sexualité UMR 8238, CNRS – Paris 8 - Paris OUEST, 27, rue Paul Bert, Ivry-sur-Seine Cedex, 94204, France
Abstract: The empirical study described in this chapter used grounded theory methodology to investigate adults’ accounts of their interest in and use of MOOC. Seventy-two Italian respondents were interviewed, all of them aged over 50. It was found that the participants shared a common eagerness to use MOOC, but only as one of several means of enhancing their cultural and professional experience. They recognised the growing importance of using the Internet, through computers, tablets, and mobile phones, and a variety of formal, non-formal and informal e-learning technologies as alternatives to more traditional leisure and cultural activities. Their awareness of their competence in using technology for learning scopes was linked to their cultural interests. They showed little or no interest in interacting with other participants or tutors and were critical about completing multiple-choice quizzes. The study findings illustrate how the participants’ use of MOOC and other learning technologies is seen as relevant and offers meaningful and age appropriate experiences. The theoretical and practical implications of the results are also discussed. © Springer International Publishing AG, part of Springer Nature 2018.
Index Keywords: Computer science; Computers; E-learning technology; Empirical studies; Grounded theory; Learning technology; Multiple choice; Professional experiences; Cellular telephone systems

Authors: Galanis N., Mayol E., Alier M., Casany M.J.
Title: An informal learning support framework
Source title: 6th Research in Engineering Education Symposium: Translating Research into Practice, REES 2015
Affiliations: UPC-BarcelonaTech, Barcelona, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Galanis, N., UPC-BarcelonaTech, Barcelona, Spain; Mayol, E., UPC-BarcelonaTech, Barcelona, Spain; Alier, M., UPC-BarcelonaTech, Barcelona, Spain; Casany, M.J., UPC-BarcelonaTech, Barcelona, Spain
Abstract: Informal learning is widely recognized as one of the main facilitators of personal and professional improvement. Its importance is even more prevalent in contexts like engineering where the constant new technological developments create an ever evolving pool of knowledge. This recognition has led to the development of a number of tools that aim to facilitate and promote informal learning, as well as to showcase the progression and acquired competences of the learners. In this paper we detail our on-going work towards creating a software framework aiming to support informal learning by providing a set of social tools including showcasing, a recommendation engine and a peer assessment infrastructure.
Index Keywords: Computer programming; Engineering research; In contexts; Informal learning; Peer assessment; Software frameworks; Technological development; Engineering education

Authors: Krüger M., Diercks-O'Brien G.
Title: Cooperative and self-directed learning with the learning scenario VideoLearn: Engineering education using lecture recordings
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: ELearning Service Abteilung (Elsa), Leibniz Universität Hannover, Hanover, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Krüger, M., ELearning Service Abteilung (Elsa), Leibniz Universität Hannover, Hanover, Germany; Diercks-O'Brien, G., ELearning Service Abteilung (Elsa), Leibniz Universität Hannover, Hanover, Germany
Abstract: Self-directed and cooperative learning through lectures? Is this not a contradiction, as lectures per se are instructional in nature? In this paper we will present the learning scenario VideoLearn and provide a differentiated response to this question. It will be demonstrated that it is possible to unite these two seemingly contrary concepts. We will give specific design recommendations to practitioners planning to use VideoLearn, as well as share with them our practical experience in employing this learning scenario at the Institute of Communications Technology at the Leibniz Universität Hannover. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2013.
Author Keywords: Cooperative learning; Design-based research; Educasting; Learning scenario; Lecture recording; Self-directed learning; VideoLearn

Authors with affiliations: Slattery, B., University of Illinois at Chicago, 1240 W. Harrison St., Chicago, IL 60607, United States
Abstract: Interpreters in informal learning spaces need to effectively reach many visitors when facilitating digital, performative exhibits. My research concerns how interpreters can be supported in dynamically distributing facilitation and attention across multiple modes of visitor participation. My preliminary approach and results are summarized below. © ISLS.

Authors: Roussou M.
Title: Users at the center of designing informal learning experiences
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Makebelieve Design and Consulting, University of Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Roussou, M., Makebelieve Design and Consulting, University of Athens, Greece
Abstract: Designing interactive learning experiences for informal educational settings, such as museums, presents challenges due to the particularities of context. In this presentation, the implications of applying user modeling and human computer interaction methods in the design of informal digital learning experiences will be highlighted. The discussion will be based on the example of the CHESS project and its formative and summative evaluation effort in two museums. © 2013 Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.

Title: Study on a learning website of self-directed english study
Source title: Advances in Intelligent Systems and Computing
Affiliations: Chinese People's Armed Police Force Academy, Langfang, Hebei 065000, China
Authors with affiliations: Yan, P., Chinese People's Armed Police Force Academy, Langfang, Hebei 065000, China
Abstract: The new study requirement is put forward based on the rapid development and application of the new information technology and network technology. The theory of CALL is studied and a learning website is developed. Thus the individual and self-directed study is realized through this practice. © 2013 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Han Y.
Title: Issues of interaction in pure-online English learning environment through perspectives of cognitive constructivism and social constructivism: A case study for non-formal learning
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Faculty of Foreign Languages, Open University of China, 160, Fuxingmennei Street, Beijing 100031, China
Authors with affiliations: Han, Y., Faculty of Foreign Languages, Open University of China, 160, Fuxingmennei Street, Beijing 100031, China
Abstract: Most previous studies on the use of Internet technology and computers for second language learning have been conducted in blended learning environments. Although much research has been undertaken into interactions in online learning, little work has focused on online English learning, let alone the pure-online (ie non-blended) English learning environment with no face-to-face element. This paper investigates the English-language learning interactions in one of our projects that has been running for ten years continuously in cooperation with the BBC and British Council. Our pure-online English-language learning environment for non-formal learning is at in2english.com.cn. This study further aims to explore how the interactions work in such an environment, and investigates the related issues and peculiar characteristics of the interactions in practice. © 2011 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Ehlers A.U.-D., Steinert A.
Title: "Transfer"-"tutor"-"coach"- "network" -the emerging social value of learning
Source title: Proceedings of the IADIS International Conference e-Learning 2010, Part of the IADIS Multi Conference on Computer Science and Information Systems 2010, MCCSIS 2010
Affiliations: University of Duisburg Essen, Universitaetsstr. 2, 45141 Essen, Germany; FOM University of Applied Science, Sigsfeldstr. 5, 45141 Essen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Ehlers, A.U.-D., University of Duisburg Essen, Universitaetsstr. 2, 45141 Essen, Germany; Steinert, A., FOM University of Applied Science, Sigsfeldstr. 5, 45141 Essen, Germany
Abstract: The following article seeks to answer the question how existing "instruction"-concepts can be extended through networks to support learners' autonomy and self-directed learning. Instruction concepts to support learners' autonomy and selfdirection are no novelty; their relevance has been discussed with changing perspectives for a long time. However, the discussion gained new relevance through the EU's economical and political motivated efforts for life-long learning as well as through studies, announcing changing learning contexts, e.g. through social networking, lately. Besides these new efforts, older ones exist, e.g. the paradigm change in education, from instructional to experience based learning, which are also decisive for the idea of Networked Learning. The paradigm shift already led to a changed perception about learning and instruction styles. However, the actual instruction concepts still refer to an "instructor" respectively coach, who can no longer be seen as always given in today's world. Networked Learning offers hence an opportunity to learn self-directed, without an instructor, tutor or coach, at any time and place. Instead, learners can draw on a worldwide resource-pool of knowledge and "peers" through networks. Networks can thus be seen as learning attendants through whom (external) stimuli, reflection and validation is given. © 2010 IADIS.
Author Keywords: Collaborative learning; Instruction concepts; Networks; Self-directed learning
Index Keywords: Collaborative learning; Experience-based learning; Instruction concepts; Learning context; Life long learning; Networked learning; Networks; Paradigm shifts; Self-directed learning; Social networking; Social values; Worldwide resources; Computer science; E-learning; Information systems; Lakes; Learning systems; Engineering education
